prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: N11B_B7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: GMC located next to a young OB association. The stelalr feedback from the cluster may be triggering new eisodes of star formation.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request a velocity resolution of 0.5 km/s. From our ASTE observations we found that the line-width of N11B at ~6 pc scales is about 7 km/s. It is likely that at 6 pc scale the line-width includes several velocity components and/or velocity gradients. In the 30Dor region, Indebetouw et al. (2013) resolves clumps wtih line-widths of about 2-5 km/s. Thus, we expect that the requested resolution is the adequate to resolve the different components.

We propose to map N11B in the CO(3-2) line emission. The mosaic consists on 145 pointings which comprise a 30x20 pc^2 region. This area was chosen guided by our ASTE CO(3-2) observations, and is the adecuate to include the densest molecular regions. The requested angular resolution of 1.1 arcsec (~0.2 pc at the distance of the LMC) is the needed to identify filaments and clumps within the GMC. In the N159 region of the LMC, Fukui et al. (2015) found filaments with typical widths if 0.5-1 pc, and thus massive clumps might be smaller. Galactic massive clumps are observed to have similar sizes. ACA observations are needed to recover the total flux from the GMCs and trace more diffuse gas.

We request 1 hour total integration time with the 12-m array, which will provide 1-sigma sensitivity of 300 mK for a spectral resolution of 0.5 km/s.
We estimate the needed sentitivity in two ways, (1) from our CO(3-2) ASTE observations and (2) from 30Dor ALMA observations obtained during Cycle 0.
Based on our ASTE data cube, we find that we need to probe CO(3-2) emitting gas at 0.5 K (as seen in the channel maps). We expect this emission to come from filaments/clumps of about 1 pc size. Correcting by the dilution on the ASTE beam (22 arcsec), and applying a beam filling factor of 0.1 to account for several components within the beam, we need to probe CO emitting gas at 1.4 K. The requested sensitivity ensures detection with a signal-to-noise ratio larger than 5.
In the 30Dor star forming region in the LMC, using ALMA observations at ~0.4 pc resolution, Indebetouw et al. (2013) measures comparable values. Temperatures of clumpy/filamentary structures are 2-60 K, with linewidths of about 2-5 km/s. Since our target have similar characteristics as the molecular clouds in 30 Dor (from single dish observations at 23", both regions have peak temperatures of CO(2-1) of about 5 K), we request a sensitivity of 0.3 K in order to identify filaments and massive clumps in the N11 region.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: N11I_B7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: GMC located where there is no assocaited free-free emission. Quiscent cloud.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request a velocity resolution of 0.5 km/s. From our ASTE observations we found that the line-width of N11I at ~6 pc scales is about 6 km/s. It is likely that at 6 pc scale the line-width includes several velocity components and/or velocity gradients. In the 30Dor region, Indebetouw et al. (2013) resolves clumps wtih line-widths of about 2-5 km/s. Thus, we expect that the requested resolution is the adequate to resolve the different components.

We propose to map N11I in the CO(3-2) line emission. The mosaic consists on 149 pointings which comprise a 25x23 pc^2 region. This area was chosen guided by our ASTE CO(3-2) observations, and is the adecuate to include the densest molecular regions. The requested angular resolution of 1.1 arcsec (~0.2 pc at the distance of the LMC) is the needed to identify filaments and clumps within the GMC. In the N159 region of the LMC, Fukui et al. (2015) found filaments with typical widths if 0.5-1 pc, and thus massive clumps might be smaller. Galactic massive clumps are observed to have similar sizes. ACA observations are needed to recover the total flux from the GMCs and trace more diffuse gas.

We request 1 hour total integration time with the 12-m array, which will provide 1-sigma sensitivity of 300 mK for a spectral resolution of 0.5 km/s.
We estimate the needed sentitivity in two ways, (1) from our CO(3-2) ASTE observations and (2) from 30Dor ALMA observations obtained during Cycle 0.
Based on our ASTE data cube, we find that we need to probe CO(3-2) emitting gas at 0.5 K (as seen in the channel maps). We expect this emission to come from filaments/clumps of about 1 pc size. Correcting by the dilution on the ASTE beam (22 arcsec), and applying a beam filling factor of 0.1 to account for several components within the beam, we need to probe CO emitting gas at 1.4 K. The requested sensitivity ensures detection with a signal-to-noise ratio larger than 5.
In the 30Dor star forming region in the LMC, using ALMA observations at ~0.4 pc resolution, Indebetouw et al. (2013) measures comparable values. Temperatures of clumpy/filamentary structures are 2-60 K, with linewidths of about 2-5 km/s. Since our target have similar characteristics as the molecular clouds in 30 Dor (from single dish observations at 23", both regions have peak temperatures of CO(2-1) of about 5 K), we request a sensitivity of 0.3 K in order to identify filaments and massive clumps in the N11 region.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: N11D_B7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: GMC located where there is no assocaited free-free emission. Quiscent cloud.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request a velocity resolution of 0.5 km/s. From our ASTE observations we found that the line-width of N11D at ~6 pc scales is about 4 km/s. It is likely that at 6 pc scale the line-width includes several velocity components and/or velocity gradients. In the 30Dor region, Indebetouw et al. (2013) resolves clumps wtih line-widths of about 2-5 km/s. Thus, we expect that the requested resolution is the adequate to resolve the different components.

We propose to map N11D in the CO(3-2) line emission. The mosaic consists on 115 pointings which comprise a 20x25 pc^2 region. This area was chosen guided by our ASTE CO(3-2) observations, and is the adecuate to include the densest molecular regions. The requested angular resolution of 1.1 arcsec (~0.2 pc at the distance of the LMC) is the needed to identify filaments and clumps within the GMC. In the N159 region of the LMC, Fukui et al. (2015) found filaments with typical widths if 0.5-1 pc, and thus massive clumps might be smaller. Galactic massive clumps are observed to have similar sizes. ACA observations are needed to recover the total flux from the GMCs and trace more diffuse gas.

We request 1 hour total integration time with the 12-m array, which will provide 1-sigma sensitivity of 300 mK for a spectral resolution of 0.5 km/s.
We estimate the needed sentitivity in two ways, (1) from our CO(3-2) ASTE observations and (2) from 30Dor ALMA observations obtained during Cycle 0.
Based on our ASTE data cube, we find that we need to probe CO(3-2) emitting gas at 0.5 K (as seen in the channel maps). We expect this emission to come from filaments/clumps of about 1 pc size. Correcting by the dilution on the ASTE beam (22 arcsec), and applying a beam filling factor of 0.1 to account for several components within the beam, we need to probe CO emitting gas at 1.4 K. The requested sensitivity ensures detection with a signal-to-noise ratio larger than 5.
In the 30Dor star forming region in the LMC, using ALMA observations at ~0.4 pc resolution, Indebetouw et al. (2013) measures comparable values. Temperatures of clumpy/filamentary structures are 2-60 K, with linewidths of about 2-5 km/s. Since our target have similar characteristics as the molecular clouds in 30 Dor (from single dish observations at 23", both regions have peak temperatures of CO(2-1) of about 5 K), we request a sensitivity of 0.3 K in order to identify filaments and massive clumps in the N11 region.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: N11I_N11D_B3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: GMC located next to a young OB association. The stelalr feedback from the cluster may be triggering new eisodes of star formation.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We request a velocity resolution of 0.5 km/s. From our SEST observations at CO(1-0) we found N11I and N11D have line-width of about 6 km/s at ~6 pc scales. It is likely that at 6 pc scale the line-width includes several velocity components and/or velocity gradients. In the 30Dor region, Indebetouw et al. (2013) resolves clumps wtih line-widths of about 2-5 km/s. Thus, the requested resolution is the adequate to resolve the different components.

We propose to map N11I and N11D in the CO(1-0) line emission. The first and second mosaic consist on 39 and 30 pointing, respectively, covering regions of 33x43 pc^2 and 22x50 pc^2. These regions are the adequate to include individual GMCs.
The requested angular resolution of 2.1 arcsec (0.5 pc at the distance of the LMC) is the needed to identify filaments and massive clumps within the GMC. In the N159 region of the LMC, Fukui et al. (2015) found filaments with typical widths if 0.5-1 pc, and thus massive clumps might be smaller. Galactic massive clumps are observed to have similar sizes. ACA observations are needed to recover the total flux from the GMCs and trace more diffuse gas.

We request 2 hour total integration time with the 12-m array to observe 2 GMCs. The observations will provide 1-sigma sensitivity of 600 mK for a spectral resolution of 0.5 km/s.
In the 30Dor star forming region in the LMC, using ALMA observations at ~0.4 pc resolution, Indebetouw et al. (2013) measures comparable values. Temperatures of clumpy/filamentary structures are 2-60 K, with linewidths of about 2-5 km/s. Since our target have similar characteristics as the molecular clouds in 30 Dor (from single dish observations at 23", both regions have peak temperatures of CO(2-1) of about 5 K), and we request a sensitivity of 0.6 K in order to identify filaments and massive clumps in the N11 region at a signal-to-noise ratio larger than 3.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to map the cold molecular gas in three Giant Molecular Clouds (GMC) in our neighbor galaxy the Large Magelanic Cloud (LMC), at subparsec resolution. We target GMCs at different evolutionary sequence; a GMC harbouring a massive cluster, a quiescent massive cloud, and an intermediate cloud associated to a less massive OB association. We propose to observe the J=1-0 and 3-2 transition lines of the CO molecule as well as dust continuum emission at 1.3 and 3 mm. These ALMA observations will probe the filamentary structure and massive clumps within the three GMCs. We aim to study the star formation activity within GMCs at different evolutionary stages, and compare the properties of their filaments and massive clumps within the framework of GMC evolution.
